newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAfrica Manuel hopes for Telkom cash in 1996/97 yr.
newsitem.headline: SAfrica Manuel hopes for Telkom cash in 1996/97 yr.

text.p: Finance Minister Trevor Manuel said on Tuesday he hoped the partial privatisation of South Africa's Telkom telecommunications corporation would be completed within the fiscal year ending March 31.
Manuel told a news briefing the government would not adopt a rigid formula for the application of privatisation funds.
He said some of the proceeds would be applied to reducing the national debt, some would go to infrastructure and some might be retained within the corporation concerned.
"Retirement of debt versus upgrading of infrastructure...It's something we would monitor fairly closely rather than adopt a knee-jerk 50-50 split between debt retirement and infrastructure," he said.
Minister of Posts, Telecommunications and Broadcasting Jay Naidoo on Monday announced a shortlist of four foreign candidates to buy up to 30 percent of the state-owned telecommunications corporation.
Naidoo said on Tuesday he expected a decision on what will be South Africa's first major privatisation deal by late March or early April.
Naidoo has estimated that the package, likely to include a human resource development plan and a commitment to service delivery, is likely to include a cash component of up to six billion rand.
"I'm hoping that we see that before the close of this fiscal year," Manuel said on Tuesday.
He said the income would be divided amongst Telkom projects, debt redemption and other infrastructural needs.
"Part of it has to be tied into the upgrading of the telecommunications capability (but)...there's other kinds of infrastructure needed that can unleash enormous economic potential," he said.
